<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GetFsInfo:
```c
int32 OS_GetFsInfo(os_fsinfo_t *filesys_info)
{
    OS_object_iter_t iter;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(filesys_info);

    memset(filesys_info, 0, sizeof(*filesys_info));

    filesys_info->MaxFds     = OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES;
    filesys_info->MaxVolumes = OS_MAX_FILE_SYSTEMS;

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_FileSysFilterFree, NULL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM, &iter);
    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        ++filesys_info->FreeFds;
    }
    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_FileSysFilterFree, NULL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_FILESYS, &iter);
    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        ++filesys_info->FreeVolumes;
    }
    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_GetFsInfo:
typedef struct
{
    uint32 MaxFds;      /**< @brief Total number of file descriptors */
    uint32 FreeFds;     /**< @brief Total number that are free */
    uint32 MaxVolumes;  /**< @brief Maximum number of volumes */
    uint32 FreeVolumes; /**< @brief Total number of volumes free */
} os_fsinfo_t
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
memset(filesys_info, 0, sizeof(*filesys_info));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The memset call itself is safe provided filesys_info points to a valid os_fsinfo_t object (OS_CHECK_POINTER checks for non-NULL). A violation would occur if the caller supplies a NULL pointer (if OS_CHECK_POINTER is ineffective/disabled), a dangling pointer, or a pointer to an object smaller than sizeof(os_fsinfo_t) (e.g. a different/shorter buffer); in those cases memset(filesys_info, 0, sizeof(*filesys_info)) would write beyond the object's bounds.
